headline.print_headline: Noodles: Friend or Foe? S. Koreans Defend Diet
headline.main: Noodles: Friend or Foe? S. Koreans Defend Diet

docs.lead_paragraph: Kim Min-koo has an easy reply to new American research that hits South Korea where it hurts — in the noodles. Drunk and hungry just after dawn, he rips the lid off a bowl of his beloved fast food, wobbling on his feet but still defiant over a report that links instant noodles to health hazards.

headline.print_headline: Nutrition: It’s Time to Reel In the Ramen
headline.main: Instant Noodles Tied to Heart Risk

docs.abstract: Women who ate instant noodles at least twice a week were 68 percent more likely to have metabolic syndrome.
docs.snippet: Women who ate instant noodles at least twice a week were 68 percent more likely to have metabolic syndrome.

headline.print_headline: New York City Grand Jury to Hear Police Choke-Hold Case
headline.main: New York City Grand Jury to Hear Police Choke-Hold Case

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York City prosecutor said on Tuesday he will present evidence to a grand jury next month to determine whether anyone should be criminally charged in the death of an unarmed man who police put in a choke hold while arresting him.
docs.snippet: A New York City prosecutor said on Tuesday he will present evidence to a grand jury next month to determine whether anyone should be criminally charged in the death of an unarmed man who police put in a choke hold while arresting him.

headline.print_headline: Tech Investor Gets Five Towns to Join Social-Health Experiment
headline.main: Tech Investor Gets Five Towns to Join Social-Health Experiment

docs.lead_paragraph: Technology investor Esther Dyson thinks she has found the answer to America's growing health concerns, and has enlisted five smaller cities across the country to try and prove it.
docs.snippet: Technology investor Esther Dyson thinks she has found the answer to America's growing health concerns, and has enlisted five smaller cities across the country to try and prove it.

headline.print_headline: Medicare to Start Paying Doctors Who Coordinate Needs of Chronically Ill Patients
headline.main: Medicare to Start Paying Doctors Who Coordinate Needs of Chronically Ill Patients

docs.abstract: Obama administration is planning to pay monthly fees to doctors who manage care for Medicare beneficiaries with two or more chronic conditions; major policy change comes amid growing evidence that patients with chronic illnesses suffer from disjointed, fragmented care; new initiative will adopt techniques devised by health maintenance organizations.
docs.lead_paragraph: Starting in January, Medicare will pay monthly fees to doctors who manage care for patients with two or more chronic conditions like heart disease, diabetes and depression.
docs.snippet: Starting in January, Medicare will pay monthly fees to doctors who manage care for patients with two or more chronic conditions like heart disease, diabetes and depression.

headline.print_headline: Kimball Teams With Wilkins on Diabetes Awareness
headline.main: Kimball Teams With Wilkins on Diabetes Awareness

docs.lead_paragraph: Basketball Hall of Famer Dominique Wilkins plans to take a spin around an IndyCar track.
docs.snippet: Basketball Hall of Famer Dominique Wilkins plans to take a spin around an IndyCar track.
